review_title: Sad time for employees of RL
pros: Up until this week, I thought I could work here for my whole career...before I watched my friends be removed.  I do like that this company (at least used to) give you an opportunity to learn and grow. It seems that movement between departments and areas is easy. You could start in the warehouse and end up in an office.
cons:
When I started, I was told this was a hire to retire company. I loved that about here. Then one day, I watched my friends get taken out. The layoffs weren't even reasonable. They removed people with the greatest seniority and the oldest in age. Sometimes whole departments were gone except one or two people. My team was lucky and only lost 2...but I'm not sure that was good really because they were the ones with the most experience. We were left with nothing. Before the people were even escorted out, their outlook access was turned off. Their meetings disappeared from calendars. Their work saved on their computers was gone. The ones of us left cannot keep up with the work they did when we cannot even access their information. I understand that sometimes layoffs are a necessary evil, but this process and the people chosen was truly evil. 

Before the layoffs, I had no negative experience with this company at all. Now, I am at an extreme frustration level and don't know if I can continue working for a place that can do that to their most loyal people.

job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: Large budget for development.  Design driven company with strong focus on quality. Your experience is largely based on your manager and others you need to work with on a daily bases.  You need a strong supportive manager to advance your career.  There are some excellent managers, but also a lot of poor ones.  There is no guidance or training for managers, which means there are no standards on how a manager should develop or treat their team.  This is open to interpretation and the discretion of each manager, which can be good or extremely bad.
cons:
Employees with unprofessional working styles and poor treatment of others lower on the hierarchy are tolerated.  The company creates an unsafe environment for open discussion about these issues.  An employee will fear retaliation for bringing these issues to HR.
Hierarchical structure where you are treated and respected based on your title.  There is a strong internal culture, which needs to be respected and followed in order to develop your career here.  If you operate outside the “cultural rules” you will not succeed.

review_title: An amazing experience for high performers; but just another day in retail for everyone else.
pros: The opportunity to travel nationally and internationally for various corporate projects if you stand out. The organization teaches you great leadership skills- actual leadership skills you'll apply when you leave the retail game. The customer in stores is also very friendly, and a pleasure to work with. In my two years I've come across a few odd customers, but never one I thought was rude or unpleasant.
cons: Without a doubt, the most inefficient business in the industry. Almost impossible to manage poor performers out of the building. Talent outside the business is seen as more valuable than talent within. Countless times I've been unable to move outstanding direct reports up because executives find a fresh resume more attractive; only to have outside candidates fail miserably because of high pressures.

job_title: Executive Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Started working about a year before all major layoffs....that's when Steffan Larson came along as CEO (he's not anymore).  Times were good but I could see how a major restructure was needed.   I escaped that round of layoffs and was able to work for another team, but was recently a 'victim'.  I absolutely loved my time at RL....pay was excellent, job was good but no real structure, but the best part of my day was the people I worked with.  Spending all of your days with people who you see more than your own family and friends leaves a lasting impression on you and I miss them all everyday.  I took care of them, and they made my days wonderful.  Great discounts and fun work activities yearly.
cons: Now is probably not the best time to work for this company as they are still doing layoffs and restructuring, but I am hoping that at some point they bring me back.

pros:
My bosses were both amazing and I loved the rest of my team. 
The program is a rotational, so you have two positions which was cool. 
The ending group project is great to add to a resume. 
There were events for the interns. 
The group of interns are all friendly with each other.
cons:
I didn't get to chose my brand or job function- they look at your resume and chose for you. 
There was always drama somewhere and people talking behind other people's back. 
The company has fallen on hard times and moral can be low. The CEO changed while  I was there, so hopefully this is starting to turn around. 
The RL clothes are often ugly, but we sold them anyways and I don't know why. 
It is such a big company, so if your starting out at the bottom, your job will be very focused- you could spend all day just analyzing buttons and that would be your whole job. 
Not much room to progress in the compay.

job_title: Operations and Logistics Manager in New York, NY
pros: There were a lot of rewards for working for RL for a long time. Such as your personal time off. After five and ten years you get an additional week off.
cons:
The company is WAY too top heavy. And it showed during the mass layoffs a few years ago. It can be clique-y at the top and the regular day to day employees suffer for it. 

Also, there is not a single person who will tell Mr. Lauren bad news or if something is a bad idea. Everyone (higher ups) is too busy trying to jockey in to his favor and not enough truth telling.

job_title: Production Manager in New York, NY
pros: RL is very stable and has a lot of passionate, hard working people.  The company has done well to inspire a feeling that employees are in a Polo family/fraternity.  Benefits and corporate holidays are good as well.  Quality brand and product.  Great discount.
cons: The expectation isn't always reasonable in terms of hours put in. Although stable (fewer layoffs than other companies I've seen), they keep a lean staff.  Often times it feels like we are expected to do more with less - goals increased, resources decreased.  I don't feel the salaries are very competitive.

review_title: Don't let the "Beautiful Brand" fool you. Corporate behind the scenes is a cultural mess.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The Brand recognition is a Pro, but Brand recognition no longer off sets the lack of consistent leadership vision execution, major turnover, and sad decline in relevance, culture and overall morale.
cons: Company is no longer growing. People, culture and talent are not a priority or truly valued - financials and politics are. Most of management are either miserable or scared. The strongest talent does not stay anymore during a time when the company needs its "stars" the most. Compensation is not competitive. Political in-fighting across departments. Diversity within Senior Management, Corporate and Business leadership has become shockingly non existent for a company of this size. Clueless, disorganized, untrustworthy HR leadership.

review_title: Ralph Lauren Can Open Doors but Limit Personal Growth
pros: Working at a corporation as long-standing and financially stable as Ralph Lauren can be an incredible experience, you have the opportunity to work with all of the biggest names in the industry from top retailers to the best vendors across the globe and because of the very cushy financial situation you are able to work on a lot of development which can be great for learning and general experience.
cons: There is a lot of creative oversight by upper management which can be good but can also be incredible scattered and often times different people are pushing for development in completely different directions, managing this oversight leads to a lot of over-development which is time consuming and can really kill morale. It also means that a lot of time is spent on inter-office politics rather than intelligent and thoughtful development.

pros:
Great discount!

Learn a lot about clothing and how it's made, and how it will fit each customer.

Very easy to get hired! Will hire pretty much anyone!

Great  job for high school students, or college students still living at home.
cons:
Management is very "robotic" has no sense of feeling, respect or compassion for employees.

Most of the managers didn't even know my name after 3 months of working there.

Scheduling is done by a computer, so no room for change is allowed.

"On Call" shifts mean waiting around all day until it's time for your invisible shift to call and see whether or not you work.

Highest turnover rate in our area.

Treat employees like cattle ment only to fold shirts.

Max hours per week for part time employees is 20 hrs.

So many employees creates feeling of anomosity. 

Dress code is very strict, and pretty much force you to purchase as many things "Polo" as possible.

The main interest is made very obvious that it is only about money. Not customer satisfaction.

Employees not allowed to talk to each other. At all.

Managers often forgot about employee breaks and you are not allowed to leave the store on your break. You must remain in the break room.

job_title: Part Time Sales Associate in Houston, TX
pros: I worked at the Houston location when it first opened. My co-workers were friendly, encouraging, and didn't take themselves too seriously. The managers were also generally very sweet and accommodating of my needs as a full-time student. My impression of the company overall and upper management was very positive.
cons: I know the managers had a lot on their hands with the opening of a brand new store and I have to cut the managers some slack for that reason, but it was such a mess. Directions on how to price and arrange the product constantly changed (we could spend a whole shift rearranging everything in the stock room only to come in the next day and be asked to undo all our work). There seemed to be a lot of confusion and argumentation among the managers as to what needed to be done and unfortunately that strife spilled over to the rest of us. Maybe that's just the way of retail, but I felt that the atmosphere was demoralizing and stressful. It wasn't worth the $10/hr they were paying me, and I exited without any pangs of regret.

pros: undeniably the product and talent at this brand is the best in the industry and everyone works hard to do their part - even if it's not appreciated.  There is a lot of pride in the brand and the product  The offices are beautiful and the perks are great (clothing discounts, special events, etc).
cons: difficult corporate culture to crack - and information is held tightly by the inner circle.... leaving the rest of the company wondering what is going on.   middle level employees are left confused by regular restructures that are never fully explained or executed before the next restructure comes along.  Leadership is continuously changing and it can be difficult to know who to follow.

review_title: Not the best place for growth
job_title: Shop Manager in Sherman Oaks, CA
pros:
- competitive starting salary ($50K annual)

- flew us to NYC for training
cons:
- boosting my shop +10% above sales was not enough, constantly asked why I wasn't selling more 

- too much time taken off sales floor for silly reports about the latest trend when they could simply pull reports

- too much time taken off sales floor completing one on one phone calls and group conference calls 

- not enough visits by my Brand Manager 

-asked to wear Lauren Ralph Lauren clothes, with no discount through Ralph Lauren 

-was there over a year, and never received a review of performance, or a raise (even though my numbers were up)

- shot down when asked how I become a Brand Ambassador

review_title: Unrecognised, long hours, little respect and no career progress
pros: Mainly the people as its a young workforce in Geneva. Work/Social life is balanced if you wish it. Benefits include discounts on clothes, travel and lunch subsidy.
cons: Management in ALL areas e.g. HR, Supply Chain, IT, etc are incompetant and only look at their bonus. Progress is only provided if you're willing to be obedient to your managers every command and perform a 12 hour day. Performance reviews and appraisals are not worth the Apple ipad they are written on by Directors and there is little or no training. All Directors are equivalent to Team Leaders in other companies and their lack of experience and people management are evident within the first week. As no formal qualifications are required for any roles, Directors are intellectually weak and only stay at the company for the bonus.

pros: - Ability to put such a large corporation on your resume after departing.
cons:
This company has some major management and leadership issues. In my 15 years as a business professinnal I have never encountered such poor leadership and professionalism from managers, senior managers, and even department directors. Reevaluating the competancy of individuals in leadership positions could greatly improve employee morale and ensure that talented individuals want to continue their career at Ralph Lauren.

 For such a large corporation, it baffles me that so many uneducated and incompetant employees who are in leadership roles are still employed with this company. This organization is filled with disrespectful employees who are on the payroll and are doing nothing buy wasting the companies money. At Ralph Lauren, your handwork and dedication will continuously be unnoticed.

review_title: "Luxury" Retailer is a good learning experience
pros: Good resources for learning, pay is above average for the retail industry but you need to ask for a high rate of pay.
cons:
Home Office is organized chaos. They are constantly changing promotions, scheduling for product changes, and direction for stores.  Inventory levels are all over the place. Recent restructuring of upper/ field management leads to more work for stores. Very little support for work/life balance unless you demand it.
If you are not a self starter and comfortable with ambiguity this is NOT the company for you. No structured training for managers, and you have to be able to figure things out on your own. I worked for the Factory division and there are lots of opportunities if you are willing to relocate but little support for developing strong leaders. Inconsistency of pay within store locations and districts.

job_title: Sales Associate in New York, NY
pros: Beautiful product, loved the lifestyle brand. Enjoyed being a sales associate and working with great customers. The in-store merchandising was incredible and helped create an atmosphere of unique luxe. Loved the employee discount. The Lauren family is lovely and came into our CT store often.
cons: Meeting and helping customers was the fun part of the job--interacting with the store managers was not. My particular manager was unprofessional, most of the time very unpleasant, and a real bully--having us stay long after the store closed to fold, without pay. She had her favorites (including the other associate she was sleeping with) and promoted him to manager. An associate's experience will all depend on who the manager is and how they treat people.

pros:
- good 3 week vacation policy
- good discount on clothing 
- potential for more forward company meeting todays needs
cons:
- micromanagement from vp doesn't allow for a suitable respected work environment
- constant disorganization from top down lofty goals with no path to implementation except just deal with it
- no adherence to the calendar from top level down and no clear communication on how to meet deadlines with unrealistic expectations
- no promotion or raises in sight - senior level positions not available no matter how excellent your review and work are - proverbial glass ceiling w/ no rewards

review_title: Completely toxic corporate cutlure. Drink the Koolaid or else!
job_title: Director of Retail Development in New York, NY
pros: Excellent technical knowledge to learn. Company is constantly adding value and developing and bettering its processes.
cons: Complete disregard for the value of people. Don't like something? There's the door! I traveled all over the US and Canada for this company and when it was time to replace my superior, I had no say nor the opportunity to weigh in. When I annoucned I was leaving, giving additional notice, I was treated like garbage. I was always a top performer - even given a rare award to commemorate this -  then received a bad review the final year, after I annouced I was leaving. I had never seen turnover quite like at the womenswear division of RL. It was a revolving door of people and I lasted five years!

pros: At one time the Ralph Lauren culture was something to be proud of.  There are no longer any pros working for this brand other than the discount and the customer. Working with the customer was the best part. Creating customer relationships was my favorite thing to do.
cons:
No work life balance. Worked 60+ hours a week consistently. District managers and regional directors took advantage of store level employees, spoke inappropriately about other leaders, and made negative remarks about overweight or gay or ugly managers.  They Frowned  upon hiring associates that were average looking, or had dreadlocks or were disabled and did not want such people interfacing with customers.  

The fair employment departments purpose to protect employees from unfair treatment, did nothing to help or protect employees and went as far as to believe the guilty party rather than the victim.  Upper management would lie to save their own skin and throw you under the bus  for self preservation.  The entire organization is filled with incompetent, self serving, arrogant, unprofessional people that would have no job if not for this job.

review_title: Great people to work with. Learn a lot about what luxury fashion is about
pros:
I worked at one of the retails during my college years, not as a sales clerk but as a concierge type of job. Although a part-time worker, I was treated in the same way as any other full-time colleagues. 

Im confident to say that I've learned a lot about its culture, fashion, and most importantly how to treat customers in most respectable/luxurious way. It definitely is not something that you can learn from working at a cafe/restaurant. People expect you to behave like an employee at a top-notch hotel in the world.

People that I worked with were quite amazing. Not like any other luxury fashion retails, they were quite laid-back and not pretentious at all.
cons: You can't really expect internal promotions if you are a part-time or contract at a retail. Also, there is a big gap between retail work and corporate work. I've seen some jumped to the corporate position from the retail but that rarely happens as far as I know.

job_title: Shipping and Receiving Associate in New York, NY
pros: The discount was okay and there are a lot of talented wonderful people that work for the company.
cons: There is little to no appreciation for employees that work behind the scenes. All of the incentives and accolades go to the sales staff. Upper management was HORRIBLE! They make you do a thousand jobs and nepotism there is heavy. It is a very vein environment so if you don't fit their standard of beauty (blonde hair blue eyed, preferably male) then know you will be spending the rest of your time there being treated as second class. I've been told that if I have an opinion I should keep it to myself by upper management (verbatim). There is extremely high turnover and every time someone would quit or was fired they would take months to replace them leaving the rest of the staff overworked and underpaid. There was little to no advancement within the company especially if you did not fit into the visual status quo.

job_title: Department Manager in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Nationally know fashion store with spectacular products.  Well respected by people who are not aware of the atmosphere behind the scenes.
cons: Poor leadership, lack of support, and discrimination runs rampant in the stores.  Upper management doesn't care or doesn't believe the employees.  But then doing only 1-2 store visits per year is no way to really see what's going on.    Store directors harass, bully, and discriminated against employees.  She also tried to inflict religious beliefs and made life miserable for you if you were not on the same side politically.

pros: Passion for the brand, history and heritage, team is like family, merchandise is beautiful most seasons and very timeless. Clients are wonderful and the relationships you build over time are very special.
cons: Pay is a joke at all levels and hard work isn't rewarded with increases. There is so much change happening right now and it has created a very stressful environment. Lay offs were not done in consultation with supervisors and many excellent employees were let go for salary or because they were last hired. Some that were left in position at store level are ineffective.

review_title: Pleasurable but frustrating due to inconsistency with management.
job_title: Sales Associate in Beverly Hills, CA
pros: Nice place to make new friends.  People are friendly, for the most part, unless however you have a disagreement with someone who steels your client/sale, then it's up to you to fix your problem because management refuses to get involved.  They ask that you resolve sales problems amongst yourself.
cons: work-life balance is horrible.  Random days off.  Never get a Saturday, it's mandatory to work Saturdays.  Forget experiencing what a weekend is.  One week you will have a Tuesday and Friday off and the next week you may have Monday and Thursday.  After a while you feel like every day is a Monday.  It's horrible.

pros: You have a job. if you ever make it to full time it not  a bad place to work, if you ever get that chance
cons: As a temp. They keep most as temps and never give full time job ,because we are cheap and disposable. I have worked harder than most full time people there and still have nothing to show for it. Our pay never goes up, no days off  and work much  harder than most. Still yet can be let go any given time. The only way it seems you can get anywhere in the company if you are fake, kiss butt or screw/suck someone.... really unhappy with the company that has people over departments that have no common sense! truly just a meat house ! as far as customer satisfaction well lets just say they do a lot of things hoping the the customer don't notice........

review_title: A big slow moving company with a lot of well paid lazy executives
job_title: Computer Artist/Manager in New York, NY
pros: Met some great hard working people. Workers who love the brand and care about it's future. And despite many obstacles they still manage to move mountains.
cons: Company is sooo top heavy. RL hires people who do absolutely nothing at the company but collect a paycheck. And he empowers coke heads to run his most favorite parts of the business like the in-house stylists. The corporate culture promotes back stabbing, ganging up on each other, not taking responsibility for ones work, bullying and fear. An in-house worker survey revealed wide spread dissatisfaction the the shock if the executive team! This is so telling of what the corporate culture is like. Also, their salaries are a joke!

review_title: Terrible place to work - employees are lied to and don't get any hours
pros: The employee discount was ok.
cons: I was promised 20 hours a week when I was hired.  The only time I got more than 12 hours was Black Friday week.  Normal schedule was one four hour shift and 3 on-calls that were never used.  So you are basically working a part-time "job" for four hours a week.  Instead of giving more hours to current empolyees, management was constantly hiring new people - I suppose to give them a couple of hours a week, too.  If you like clothes and like a discount I suppose this is ok.  If you are trying to pay bills, Polo makes this absolutely impossible.  Barely made enough money to pay for the gas to get to work.  If you value your sanity, if you want to make some money, DO NOT WORK FOR POLO.  Just warning you.  Go somewhere else where you will get hours and some respect.

review_title: Great place to learn, best designers of the industry
job_title: Interior Design Manager in New York, NY
pros: Ralph Lauren is one of the most important Fashion Houses in the world.  Working here brands your resume and gives you the opportunity to work with great designers.  From John Varvatos to Thoms O'Brien, these are only a couple of names of the great designers that have walked thru the halls of Ralph Lauren.  You get access to the best vendors and a world class education on very detailed design
cons: Unfortuntately since RL went public, the creativity has been very limited, the perks have gone down, salaries are low and therefore all the great designers don't stay long.  The company is very top heavy, which is very discouraging for the bottom tier and for the top tier, well....they dont do much.

review_title: Welcome to the Horrible World of Ralph Lauren
pros: Discount.... Oh wait, I have to type twenty words.  Ok, well let me put it more extensively.  Working at Polo, one receives a 50% discount on full price merchandise.  50% can still be too much with the average product costing several hundred dollars.  But the discount is the only pro.
cons: Management was completely inept and the culture of the company is such that any changes that should be made are simply impossible.  Big Brother was in full effect while on the job and everybody walks on egg shells the whole time.  The commission based sales is fine but there is no rules governing the staff so it is usually like throwing a steak to hungry dogs.  A horrible corporate culture that gets lost in the "glamour" of a high fashion company- you could be selling 2x4s at Home Depot with more class than this place.

pros: Coworkers were happy to come to work, often early as well as offering to stay late. The culture was warm, friendly, positive and constructive. Feedback was constant from peers and management. Structure allowed for in-depth learning and developing of merchandising skills quickly. Register Trained in 2 weeks. Coming into retail with no experience I felt fairly paid (by the hour). Company discount is huge. Asked to do in-house modeling, paid well. Breaks are incredibly flexible. Management was down to earth, supportive and assertive.
cons: Training was simple. If you wanted to learn about each and every detail of the products it was up to you to really show you cared. It's a big ask of a company like Ralph Lauren because their brand is so diverse.

pros:
- 30% staff discount
- 50% discount on friends and family events
cons:
- They rarely ever till train employees, some of my colleagues had been there over a year and still hadn't been till trained.
- They just get you to fold clothes for your whole shift
- There's nothing productive to do
- They don't respect your availability and often give extra hours and then moan if you can't do the overtime (you're legally allowed to refuse overtime hours)
- There's no respect for student employees with their studies and timetables
* MY SUPERVISOR TOLD ME MY TOP PRIORITY IS WORKING FOR RALPH LAUREN AND THAT MY DEGREE MUST COME SECOND*
- Management don't do anything apart from sit on their backsides and drink coffee all day having a chat
- Management don't even know what they're doing and what their responsibilities are
- Supervisors treat you like idiots and spy on you
- Management wouldn't be able to organise a piss-up in a brewery, they're that bad.

review_title: Newly developed internship program out of the Greensboro, NC office working with Belk department stores.
job_title: Retail Development Intern in Raleigh, NC
pros: The program was highly informative and offered a great extension of coursework given at the NC State College of Textiles. Offered a look into the corporate atmosphere in the Greensboro office as well as a look at the distribution and customer service centers. Gave a comprehensive look at the company and its operations. The executives were open to suggestions regarding marketing and development of retail and department stores. Opened many doors for future success with Polo.
cons: The program in its first year was a learning curve for both the two interns as well as those in charge of the program. The loose structure was both a pro and con as it gave the opportunity to be creative but at times it left us wondering what our goals were.

pros:
Work isn't very difficult
Get to wear casual clothes daily
cons: The upper management in my department is completely demotivating. They posses the characteristics that are the complete opposite of what makes a good leader. Constantly looking to blame someone when there is a mistake. Everyone above the manager level is extremely awkward and socially inept. Micromanagement. Unwillingless to listen to ideas/suggestions that go against how they think things should be working even if the suggestion can strengthen a control or provide increased efficiency to a project. They are extremely inefficient; would rather sit and speculate for hours on why something is done a certain way when it could just be answered with a quick 10 minute phone call.

job_title: Assistant Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The employee discount on merchandise is generous. Every month associates can purchase up to  5 items of their choice at 50% off , as part of their personal wardrobe.  The hours are flexible, and the atmosphere is friendly.  Training is provided, even for the inexperienced, as long as you embody good customer service skills and behaviors, this retail gig is easy.
cons: Benchmarking associates is just a term they use when they deliver performance appraisals.  When it comes time to fill internal positions, most often they hire external candidates.  General managers don't mentor the ASM team.

job_title: Sales Associate in Palm Beach Gardens, FL
pros:
Good company to work for as a sales associate.  Just make sure you ask the right questions in your interview(s):
-Is your business consistent year round or do you have peaks/valleys? Snowbirds and others. IF so how do you work around dead periods of business.
-How often do your associates hit their quota?
-How does your store work with conversion?
-Do you have incentive programs for associates who exceed quotas?
cons: Beware of complacent managers.  See how the staff reacts to your visit.  There can be warning sings if you look closely.  I have worked at great stores and also VERY poorly run stores.  One of the best managers I've ever had was in Palm Beach Gardens (Kelly) and the worst (multiple managers) was in Atlanta... Beware of kool-aide.

pros: You are working with a leader within its industry. Being an ambassador of the brand will make you proud of your job. I cannot speak on behalf of every location, but where I work we have an amazing team. My team is like a family, and that makes the job all the more rewarding.
cons: The company just implemented a policy that requires all employees to wear uniforms. The shoes are extremely uncomfortable. Also, management always tries to keep you busy, so you will be asked to do a lot of nitty gritty things that seem pointless at times.

pros: A lot of the employees were really cool and there were a lot of hours available on night shifts.  Probably the best part about the job was the benefits. 50% off all online clothes and 20% off in the store was a really good deal and some of the best schools that I have now are fromthis job.
cons: The hours were ridiculously long especially if you were working in my chest and you would be constantly asked to stay longer so for example if you were supposed to leave at 8 o'clock you would always be asked to leave at 10 instead and put in a position where you can't say no

review_title: I liked the layed back environment, but would expect much better compensation from such a large company
pros:
-Discount
-Benefits (only if full time)
-Environment
-Large management team
-HR manager working on-site full time
-Laid back daily tasks
-Did I mention the discount??
cons:
-Very poor salary compensation, I'm not sure if it was the region that I was working in, but I believe minimum wage as a base pay is quite rediculous for a large and successful company as Polo. I don't believe it's fair at all.
-Little to no hours, there were weeks when I worked only 4 hours

review_title: Not the worst, definitely not the best
pros: The prestige of the name still carries weight.  If you're pursuing fashion you could do worse than to use it as a stepping stone, but current culture does not encourage loyalty.  Benefits are quite excellent, although they are used as a substitute for appropriate compensation.
cons: Pay is way below market. Opportunities for promotion are few and in some cases discouraged (internal career services even encourage you to 'stay where you are').  I left after a long period for another opportunity and my departure wasn't even acknowledged.  Corporate upheaval and constant changes in direction filter down to an uncertain work schedule and clear lack of guidance.

pros: Tend to have a great team that are experiencing the same issues. When it all pulls together, there can be an amazing buzz. Discount is alright and uniform can be on brand but not Ralph so cheaper alternatives are available for uniform.
cons:
Too much focus on getting young part timers into roles. Tends to be very unproductive. I had to manage a team that could, at time be entirely under 18 in a multi-million $ location
Increasing lack of training and solid processes. No clear on-boarding process, normally created manually by the store meaning theres no consistent start. 
Poor pay for the amount of work/money being made.
Can spend a long time waiting for promotion opportunities then someone will be recruited externally for a position, despite more experienced staff being available

job_title: Production Operations Manager in New York, NY
pros: Company Discount, however even with the discount, clothing is still expensive
cons: Management has no idea how to supervise. I have been with the company for over 7 years and have not grown professionally, furthermore, the salary is ridiculous. Individuals who are below my level/position at other companies make twice as much as I do. Also, if "your supervisor" does not like you, he/she will treat you like a piece of garbage. Do not work here, its a great company on paper, but this is no place to be. I rather be unemployed then deal with the humiliation and discrimination from senior management. Also, HR does not stand up for you, in fact HR makes your concerns about how management treats as if its no big deal. And senior management washes all concerns under the rug. No wonder everyone is leaving the company. People are dropping like flies.

pros:
Overall strategy and purpose clearly communicated, great leadership
Not just lip service to respect and inclusion - walks the walk!
Respected global industry leader with great opportunity for career development - just check out the who's who in fashion who have spent time honing their skills here!
Many wonderful benefits added including sabbatical, flexible workplace and scheduling options.
cons: So much to do! Balancing priorities can be challenging

job_title: Senior Product Manager in New York, NY
pros: Looks good on resume to hopefully get what’s deserved from next job based on persception of being employed here.
cons:
Too much back stabbing and people riding the high horse when really they were no better.
Brag about company wins and then when it’s time for employees reviews they have no monies for a decent cost of living wage increase.... what are we supposed to do with 1%,; bonuses go to those already
Making 6 & 7’figure salaries with additional bonuses and do least amount of work unless you call rescheduling pointless
Meetings all  day!

review_title: Fantastic Corporate Culture and Great, Supportive Management
pros: RL is the best place I've ever worked.  Not only are the benefits amazing and the employee perks enviable, the management really cares about their employees.  The organization celebrates diversity, charity, and new ideas.  I couldn't recommend it more.
cons: It is very competitive because it's a great place to work and because of the "glamour" of the brand.  I had to get in through a third party contracting agency, because the seven or so applications I submitted led to nothing, so it can take a lot of work to get your foot in the door.  Worth it, though.  Also, during peak season (Christmas), you WILL work seven days a week.  But it shouldn't be a surprise to anyone who knows retail, and management is right there in the trenches with you, so nobody is asking you to do anything they aren't doing themselves.

pros: Was one of the best places to work a few years back. Great vacation and 401k. Met many friends for life here.
cons:
So unorganized and chaotic. Senior leadership is so detached from reality and every week you just wait to see who will be let go. It is maddening to me when ceo says one team and open communication and  that is not happening.  Not sure how much longer I can watch this go on. It’s not about business but major politics and favorites.  And don’t bother going to HR as it is useless.
I put in many years here as I truly loved this place but it’s like they don’t care about their people anymore.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Opportunities to advance, travel, and competitive salary demanding on your experience.
cons: Difficult to manage family or personal life at times due to a demanding and ever changing schedule. There's a lot of pressure to look and dress a certain way in order to fit the mold of being "branded." Also, when the eliminated some of the supervisor and assistant management positions around 2014, they did so in a vicious, unprofessional way. They were given no notice, and had to just be escorted off of the property by upper management immediately once they were told. I've seen people terminated for theft treated better than how those employees were, and they had done nothing wrong.

review_title: Overall, working at Polo was a positive experience.
pros: Polo allowed me to have a very flexible work schedule.  I was able to work the opening, mid-day, or closing shift depending on what worked best for my schedule.
cons: Hours available for work is heavily dependent upon sales, so it was difficult to predict how many hours I was going to work per week.  I was often sent home hours early if we did not meet our sales benchmarks for the day.  This made it very difficult for me to create a reliable personal budget.

job_title: Full-time Women's and Children's Department Specialist in Waipahu, HI
pros:
-Competitive pay. This was my first job and my starting pay was almost 2 dollars above minimum wage for just a part time sales position.
-Positive work atmosphere.
-Employees were easy to get along with and worked well as a team.
-If you really love your job and work hard enough, you will be noticed as was I after becoming promoted to a full time specialist after about a year of part time.
cons: -Corporate was pretty messy about who they chose as GM.  Most employees always opposed the work ethic of the GM and reached out to corporate many times.  It took corporate to fix the situation a whole year.

job_title: Full Time Associate in Aurora, IL
pros:
Great pay. Never ask for minimum wage.
Always work to do, if you're the type to get bored.

Very flexible shifts.
cons:
New dress code enacted in August of 2016. Requiring all employees to wear only a navy top and chinos/dark denim. 

Idiocrity. 

Keep note Ralph himself no longer oversees this company as he did. And now, it's closing stores and ruining its image. No longer has the feel of Polo Ralph Lauren. Just a company ghosting the values and style that was once the world of Ralph Lauren.

pros: Honestly there are no pros to this company.
cons:
First off they make you buy their clothing line to work there, and only give 10% off. Secondly the management doesn't listen to the needs of their employees.  Third they schedule you on days that you can't work due to school or other obligations, and If you don't show they write you up. 
This company doesn't provide decent health insurance, and the pay is well below average. Honestly it's just above minimum wage.  Yet they expect you to buy their clothes to wear to work without a decent discount or an employee payment program to buy them.

job_title: Associate Designer in New York, NY
pros: The discount is sick and obviously the clothing is amazing. My immediate boss was fantastic she taught me a lot- my team was like family.
cons: Well the huge layoffs they had in 2015 was a huge bummer. Made the company moral very low. For many months we were all terrified of losing our jobs. Everyday we would look around and our team got smaller. And they just gave us more and more work. More work mostly because the specific brand we were working for was under going a bit of a revolution and design was at odds with merchandising so- long story short that results in design being forced to change styles sometimes more than enough times before we hit showroom. And then when we would hit showroom, everyone would panic and we would make 101 changes all over again. Most mentally exhausting job I've ever had. To do the same thing over and over and over for months for it to ultimately be changed back to what you originally designed. Literally killed my soul. Then they let my boss go and dumped everything on me. Sent me into panic, thats when I knew I had to leave.

job_title: Sales Associate/Cashier in North Charleston, SC
pros: Good pay for retail in this area, and the products sell themselves. The discount is okay. Many different schedules to work. This store has improved since last year and hopefully, it will continue to as there is room.
cons: Extreme cronyism. Some employees could sit in the back or take extended breaks and nothing would happen. If other employees did that they would get reprimanded. The favoritism dictates the level of respect an employee gets: some good workers get talked to disrespectfully. Unproductive employees who suck up to managers get lots of leeway. Productive employees are given unfair share of work sometimes. Also, a huge amount of time has to be spent on loss prevention. It can make sales exhausting.

review_title: Great people, a once-lively company goes bland corporate
job_title: Sales Person in New York, NY
pros: Great coworkers, wonderful customers who you might connect with and potentially utilize as a connections for other work, interesting product.
cons: Some competitive coworkers, sharky salespeople, pressure to sell from management, low pay and commission  compared to the price of goods being sold and wealth of the company, expectations and (relative pressure from management) that you will spend your own personal money with the brand.

pros: I now know how I wouldn't run a company
cons: All the work goes to the lower-level employees and senior management doesn't even acknowledge it. Not enough time in the day to finish my work, and not enough support from management. Most of the leadership has no managerial skill whatsoever and no interest in learning. Difficult to get promoted.

pros: I can't think of one good thing, well they give you earn time off but, you have to use that time to make up hour when they cut hours, so really you can't save them for vacation time away from this place. And you really need the time off sometimes because this Place DRAIN the life out of you.
cons: Scheduling, the schedule should be made a month in advance but it's a daily schedule changing by the hour, no Work life balance. the daily post and changing of the schedule have you where you can't interview if you'll looking for another job or if you need to go to the doctor and you will after all the HARD mental work this place does on you, at Ralph Lauren you don't have a life.

review_title: Used to be Excellent; Gone Downhill
pros: Great co-workers and pretty good location -- there was almost no traffic (compared to some locations) getting to or leaving work even during busy hours.  Good benefits (though recent changes in Health care are not good), great 401k plan.
cons: I worked in the call center and it used to be one of the best places within the company to work, but within the last 2 years, they hired new senior leadership that only cares about yes-men and dollars.  There was almost no effort to know the front-line managers. As a whole, employee morale dropped, and no one seemed to care. No employee growth development beyond CSR.

review_title: Be sure to negotiate higher salary then suggested. Also negotiate "Senior Title".
pros:
Top Fortune 500 Company \ plenty of work.
Prestige and company discounts.
Broad segments of opportunity.
Very good financial \ sound company.
Great brand with legendary recognition.
cons: Information Systems Dept is dictated by Finance division. Company is over run with consultants. Departments are very segregated and knowledge sharing is hard to come by. Does not pay more than 2% raises annually for IS staff. Career growth is hard to come by due to lack of management vision. Company does NOT support or display organization maps because they are afraid of talent poaching. Company does NOT pay for tuition reimbursement.

review_title: So Far, So Good (for right now)
pros: Not a bad place to work if you need a 2nd part-time job, very relaxing work environment and not very stressful. Management is easy-going and willing to work with you if you had any issues or need time off.  Great discount for a quality clothing line if you are an employee.
cons: Not great pay, like any retail store your enjoyment can depend on how you are treated by customers, only get 15-19 hours for part-time. Work usually very repetitious.

review_title: Provides excellent training no matter where your career leads you.
job_title: Sales Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great training and development. Excellent benefits. Excellent growth within company. Having Ralph Lauren on your resume opens the door to countless opportunities well outside the company and fashion world.
cons: TERRIBLE compensation (although benefits were a plus). Be prepared to give your entire life to the company.  Hours are horrendous and company expects you to drop everything for them at all times.  Managers instantly develop a superiority complex and are very demeaning - think they are God - and they favor gay men.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
The people ( NOT executive/senior mgt staff) are incredible.
I worked in women's design for four years and made some of the best friends I'll ever have.
Also, people OUTSIDE of the fashion industry are always impressed when they find out you work there
cons:
Nepotism!
Also, I watched men get promoted and paid more routinely. No exaggeration- and Part of my role was salary and budget overview so I knew!
Also, unfortunately, the folks I saw promoted again and again were some of the most disparaging and miserable, judgemental and completely evil people I have ever known...
It only gets you promoted if you suck up to executive staff hardcore and/or drink the kool-aid and dress like a ridiculous RL ad from the 70s.

review_title: Lots of work, low pay, no incentive
job_title: Sales Associate in Fort Myers, FL
pros: I enjoyed working with the people I worked with, for the most part.  There's always one or two grouchy managers, but almost everyone else was pleasant and easy to get along with.
cons: The work culture is atrocious.  They also push everyone to work harder and meet unrealistic sales goals, and even have the employees compete with each other to see who can rack up the most sales, but there's no incentive for doing so.  It's easier to do the bare minimum and collect your meager paycheck than it is to bury yourself in peppy busy work for the same amount of pay.

job_title: Technical Designer in New York, NY
pros: Clothing and it looks good on your resume.
cons:
A demeaning and negative environment, a lot of micro-managing and rarely any promotions from within unless you're a favorite. My boss always had something negative to say and no one did anything right. Environment was very cliquey. 
They monitor days off very closely. Extremely limited sick days and very little vacation time. If you go over the allotted amount, they dock your pay. Their health insurance is pretty bad. No bonuses unless you're management.

job_title: Sales Associate in Locust Grove, GA
pros: Great discounts, friendly managers, people in the work team are excellent.
cons: Terrible hours, horrible scheduling, mediocre pay, the hours are extremely weird and difficult. Sometimes they will give you shifts from 7pm-2am. Also, they do not keep your availability in mind. Even after telling them your only available till 11pm the latest they will always give you shifts past 11pm

job_title: Merchandise Planner in New York, NY
pros:
-great American brand; I took a lot of pride in telling people I worked there
-great way to learn the ins and outs of a major brand
-great discount!
cons:
Overall, I felt that this place did not care about employees at all. Having made it through the massive lay offs, the company didn't give me a reason to stay - morale is very low. I was doing work meant for 2-3 people, countless late nights, and upper management continued to make unrealistic demands. Too many unnecessary meetings create a lot of extra work/stress and fake deadlines. Need more workers and less management.
Promotion structure is very convoluted; takes years to move up with nominal salary increases if any.

pros: Brand recognition and desire, though fewer and fewer customers are looking for the pony to adorn their clothes, some still are.
cons: Retail is difficult, and demanding. The best employees are taken for granted, while others have exceptions and excuses made for their lack of effort and integrity. The buck never seemed to stop with management. Bad behavior, when reported, was never fully addressed. Many employees reported  issues. Those issues were left unresolved to the point that the employees were compelled to quit.

review_title: Great company, Great place to work.
pros: Great company to work for, excellent benefits including vacation, sick/personal time, and Summer Fridays. This is a company with a fabulous brand that will stand the test of time -- job security is definitely an added bonus. There is opportunity for advancement once you have proven your competence in current position.
cons: Politics, politics, politics. As with many companies, it's not what you know but who you know. During my tenure with this company (several years) I have seen many people unjustly passed over for opportunitites and promotions because someone's father knows the right VP. In the end, those who work hard and do a good job do get noticed and rewarded for their efforts, though.

pros: Brand Value, Employee Discounts, Intention to recruit Diverse Workforce
cons: Too many layoffs to start with.  No preference or incentives for lower/mid-level Employees.  Everything is controlled by a few people who are at the upper management level (Director and above).  Too much power given to external vendors than employees.  The management's attitude is like, if you don't deliver it in my way, I will get it done by external vendors.   Favoritism and regionalism at its peak in some departments.  Some supervisors used the opportunity to let go of honest and hard-working employees during layoffs.  Innovation from employees is not encouraged and no growth opportunities.   Overall a very depressing working environment.

review_title: Decent pay for retail but very negative work enviroment
pros: decent hourly pay with commision extra, they actually hire full time which is sometimes hard to find in retail, many of the other sales people are really great people
cons: Poor management, very demanding weekend and holiday hours, unpredictable schedule changes, somewhat bizarre sales expectaions at times, sales is VERY micro managed which is often counter productive to creating real relationships with clients. There are often disputes about who's client is who, who's helping who etc which is stressful and forces sales people to be more agressive. Dress expectations are hard to keep up with on what is relativly very low pay compared to normal customers, even with half price discounts.

pros: Very organized and level headed team. I was always told that there are no stupid questions except for asking if a question is stupid. Always willing to help. Plus I started with a pay above minimum wage without asking!
cons: Forced to be very bubbly and extroverted, which I know is generally expected in retail, but I felt as though it was too much. I literally felt as if I was being told to act as a different person. (and kept getting yelled to do so though my head piece.) So if you aren't really outgoing and charming off the bat, this may not be the best job for you.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bal Harbour, FL
pros: Great for your resume and relationship building.  The company is known worldwide which is always a plus and can really help with improving sales skills and tactics with a global client.  Met so many wonderful customers and had an exceptional experience customer/sales wise.
cons: The company especially the Bal Harbour location which I worked in was a complete mess internally.  The face of it is fabulous and edgy, sexy, classic, all American.  Internally it's trashy, Bad mouthed sorority/fraternity fest.  Most of the people there had landed their jobs because they were a friend.   they missed the memo that work  class and leadership is what you are looking for to build a team.

pros: None at all. Any benefit promised was taken away as soon as you sign the contract. If you like the clothes you get a decent discount
cons: The hiring process is flawed the management team hired had not enough or any relevant experience to work in luxury or in large concept stores. When I was offered my role it was misrepresented, what I was told was my dream job with lots of progression. What I got was the total opposite not given the chance to do my job and instead left to do the roles of the incompetant manager and assistant manager and hold up the business. This company is a shambles and the lack of communication and access to confidential hr advice is extraordinary. I've never worked in a company so full of under qualified and unprofessional people.

job_title: Retail Sales Associate in Blowing Rock, NC
pros: Job is pretty simple, plus the opportunities to meet people who work for large companies is an unexpected pro. The pay could be better to match with other High-End clothing retailers, but it isn't necessarily lower either. Also the discounts are  pro as well.
cons: Corporate isn't necessarily always willing to work with you on hours, company rarely ever hires from within. Also not being able to go home much for holidays with family if you're a good distance from home is a negative.

review_title: If you aren't a favorite, good luck getting promoted
job_title: Technical Designer in New York, NY
pros: Your direct counterparts will be the most amazing people you'll work with. The company happens to hire some of the best rank and file professionals in the business.
cons: Unfortunately, unless you're willing to go along to get along, or you just happen to be the last man standing, you'll never be promoted. Or you happen to be a fave of upper management. Doesn't matter if you have the skill set. Looks also matter a whole lot. If you don't have the "Ralph Lauren" look, good luck getting a good review or anything resembling any acknowledgement that you're actually good at your job.

review_title: Favoritism and bias are the buzzwords here
job_title: Associate Designer in New York, NY
pros: Learning about vintage and heritage American clothing and lifestyle. A great resource.
cons: Poor treatment of lower totem pole design staff. I worked horrifically long hours there. Racism is a real problem there but they hide it very well. Hierarchy taken far too seriously. Long hours. A lot of upper management are there only for their appearance (not necessarily for their looks) or for how well they kiss up to their superiors. Really behind on the current trends of the industry. Very biased against those who do not fit the aesthetic.

review_title: My experience working for Ralph Lauren was disconcerting as they seemed to be racist.
job_title: Model Dresser in New York, NY
pros: The people are generally nice, but most are either aloof, disingenuously cordial or blatantly do not acknowledge your presence if you are black.
cons: If you are not white forget about being treated like anything other than the help

review_title: Excellent for a resume with a High End Retailer but HORRIBLE for company morale, pay/benefits, expectations
pros: Wonderful coworkers.  The name Ralph Lauren is a plus for any resume.  Scheduling is very flexible (though never done right..see cons). Discount is 30%, sometimes special discounts online.
cons: Pay at this location is the lowest in the area.  After several years with the company, still learn I have additional responsibilities or responsibilities I have been performing are not mine.  Their interweb system is like using dial-up. Constantly get different assignments for the same project by DM, RM, GM

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The Company has a movie-like history and (on paper) an incredible culture. It still feels like Ralph travels the halls and shapes the brand because he actually does.
cons: There is a job for absolutely everything and it's difficult to have anyone do something not listed on their job description. A corporate company where you often hear "no" and a fashion company that falls under all the generic stereotypes.

review_title: Flailing with very real structural issues
pros: Standard benefits (for better or worse), discount (if you like the product), offers many opportunities between all the different brands and functions
cons: Weak leadership at almost all levels (extremely rare to find true leaders or mentors -- 99% of the time there is unclear direction or direction that changes every day, inefficiencies, passive aggressiveness, high levels of emotion -- not passion, but pure emotion), heavy politics, high tension among teams, constant disruptive change (and not disruption in the good way), shocking levels of unprofessionalism (and again not in the good innovative way), confusing and inconsistent org structures across teams, disorganization, over-complication, can be extremely backwards

job_title: Sales Associate in Blowing Rock, NC
pros: Company really tries to keep us engaged. Many incentives and rewards to encourage work performance. Holiday pay is definitely fair and they go out of their way to treat us on days that would rather be spent with family. For example Black Friday we are fed free meals and given plenty of breaks. Employee discounts are great!
cons: Pay is horrible for the amount of work they expect of a sales associate. Require late hours for floor sets and does not work well with class schedules. There is a lot of petty drama within the work place and it's not worth the time and pay.

review_title: Unbending Core Values - Warm, Welcoming Place to Work
pros: The biggest pro for working at RL are the unbending core values and family oriented culture which make this a very warm, welcoming place to work. It is a very large company with many opportunities for growth and development. Direct contact with higher ups. Fast paced environment. Great work life balance as a corporate employee (for me at least - and most other teams I've come in contact with).
cons: Decision making can be slow, and at times, not made at the lowest level which can compromise efficiency and demotivate staff level employees.  Certain areas of the company can feel somewhat siloed off.

review_title: Buyers admin assistant placement year review

pros:
Lots of company benefits
Breakfast mornings for free
Contribute to charity work
No strict dress code
cons:
Some members of management on certain departments are snappy and rude. 
Pay is not the best 
If you don’t get along with your manager there is little you can do to fix it - even after speaking to HR.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I started on the corporate side of IT back in 2011 and was looking to grow with the company. The name Ralph Lauren indicates a brand of style, comfort and luxury. They have decent benefits and severance package.
cons: The new fiscal year has brought about a huge change in the company. The talk of restructuring is just a fancy word for layoffs being inevitable. Entire departments removed or dwindled down to only a few employees. Just ask yourself is now a good time to work for this company. Perhaps it's justified as a contractor or temp. The choice is yours.

pros:
-Some nice people 
-Good product
-Nice store
cons:

-So much pressure is put on the team members

pros:

pros: Clothing discount.  Compensation package is above average.
cons: Glass ceiling.  Don't even think about getting a promotion if you are African-American.  It is a very hard glass ceiling.  There is almost no leadership that is African-American, and the company refuses to do anything about it, even though there are lots of qualified internal candidates.  Not a good place to work.

pros:
In my time at RL, I saw this company completely transform leaving its glory days behind.  I first moved to NY and worked in their intern program and it was pretty great that I was able to see so many different facets of the company. They have refined there program since then and it's much more established now. At that time they put me in a buying team for a brand and I worked my days as part of that team. The other girls were not nice and I often felt set up to fail. I kept on pushing and by the end of the internship started working in the flagship on Madison. After about a year of trying to figure out my path I found the perfect fit at corporate. 

I began working with the most talented group of people in the creative side. Times were great! The hours were always long but the connection with my team was family. I moved quickly from a coordinator to a manager in a year from working hard and being self motivated. My Senior Director took me under their wing and really cultivated my growth. I worked hard for RL. Three years into my corporate role I became a Director. It was a lot of work but I loved it. All in all the pros for my time at RL are the people I worked with.  They always took every opportunity to teach me and help me become better so that I could help the company grow. I still keep in touch with many of my RL family today.
cons:
So basically the con is that this company is no longer the company I spoke about in the pro section. They operate now with fear. I get that a company needs to make changes to grow. I totally get that. But the day RL handed over this company was the day it hit the fan. I literally saw the infrastructure crumble.  Entire departments were let go without warning. People started fearing for their jobs. But the worst part was, they were letting go the people who were producing. I saw the stores start to deteriorate. People stopped caring because there was no direction. No leadership. No cultivating growth. 

In my time, I never made what I should have. I worked so hard and was always at the bottom of the pay scale for my title. I still worked hard but I never was compensated what I actually know I deserved. 

Now I work for myself so I do appreciate all the talent I learned from and don't see my time as a total waste! It helped me get were I am today, but that is not the same RL that exists today. I left because it wasn't that company I started with. And I never looked back.

job_title: Sales Professional in Chevy Chase, MD
pros: The nicest management people that you will ever find. Great workers and good leaders.
cons: Hated the way that employers are treated when arriving of leaving the shop; there is a protocol of inspection to you and from you to your superiors that makes every one fell like thieves.  You will never earn what is promised or even close. The ones who can live from such job are those who have spent more than a decade in the store. You end working for those dinosaurs.

review_title: So happy with the brand, so sad with my career
pros:
The Brand, the standards, the American way of viewing things, the RL world, the discounts, the flexibility...
 It is really one of the best companies I have worked for or maybe the one I had more passion for.
cons: Spain. There are no careers opportunities or they do not share them with you. Too afraid of losing control or letting anyone grow higher. I wanted and already had the experience for better or international positions and all I hear from the HR is "mañana, mañana" and a year went by.

review_title: Legendary brand.  Great workplace for stoic, die hard fans of poor planning and immediate execution of changes every min
pros: Competitive salary.  Iconic Brand with loyal customer base.  Opportunity for growth if willing to travel and move frequently.  You make your own way through personal relationships if you make yourself known.  Company built on great values, but decisions don't follow them.
cons: Complicated training process for new hires.  No recruiting structure to support stores with great candidates.  Muddled time and attendance policy.  Stores always playing catch up after poor planning and sluggish decision making from the corporate offices.  Totally reactive environment that at the same time challenges you to be pro-active.  LOL.  Video shops are not a tool for anything.

pros: Great company to be a part of!  Great discounts.  Not a micro-management atmosphere.  Co-workers become 'family' and support of co-workers is tremendous.  A big 'we are all in this together' mentality.
cons: Work/Life balance is extremely tilted.  Long hours, weekends, multiple layoffs which meant even greater workload placed onto remaining employees.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
An amazing organization that is constantly adapting to grow and find new and innovative ways to not only support the business, but continue to support employees as well.

For example, employees wanted more vacation, better benefits, new programs, etc. The company delivered increased PTO, better benefits, and an entire career development program. Great ways to get involved in community service.

A truly great company that makes you feel you are part of a family.
cons: Some of the office spaces are beautiful, and others could use some revamping

pros: The people make the company. Looking back over my career at this company, it was the people that I met along the way that were the best part of the experience.
cons:
I was laid off in June along with so many long timers who were loyal to the. Brand and in return, we were let go while poor management remained behind.  The company thinks very high of itself and has often talked about what a privilege it was to work there.  This was true many years ago, but the real truth is that they became complacent and lost their edge.  Management has no foot in reality.  Nobody can make a decision there on their own. Whine to the right person and you can go far..  way too many egos for no reason.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Bosses vacation a lot, which means you have autonomy. Opportunity to travel with company for store openings. Very accomodating and they actually value a work/life balance. SUMMER FRIDAYS. Stressful work load, but everyone is great at what they do and good quality people.
cons: Takes FOREVER to get promoted. They value employees who start with them, exit to other companies and expand skill set, and then come back.

easy interview.

review_title: It's a trade off: a great place to learn the trade for very bad pay.
pros: For a creative person it's a great place to develop your skills and learn from the most talented people.

review_title: It was an overall positive experience and great for those who have a creative, self-starter attitude.
pros: I enjoyed the ability to come up with my own ideas around how to get the results and team I wanted. There was a wealth of reporting and information at my fingertips to understand the business,
cons: There was a lack of training materials and tools to use in the field. The home office also didn't support field development strongly enough. There was poor two-way dialogue between stores and home office, resulting in a disconnect between the two.

review_title: Galleria RL compared to outlet RL
pros: Working at the upscale RL like in the Galleria Houston you get paid a commission and there is allot of high $ sales so lots of money to be paid. The outlet is the opposite, completely different. It's hourly and at least you can pick your hours
cons: commission sales is VERY competitive and employees working there for a long time don't want you waiting on 'their' customers. I even had to give my time and sales to the so called claimed customers of other employees. Outlet pays low and folding and removing from dressing room is all you do it seems except stand at cash register and ring endless sales

pros: Merchandising is fun and that's about it.
cons: Compamy has no idea what direction they want to take with the Factory stores. Are we competing with fast fashion? Are we competing with the likes of Banana Republic and J Crew? Company fails to provide workable deadlines and instead releases the details of every single project the day before the project is to start...if you're lucky. This results in the management team working ridiculous shifts and breeds resentment. Company has a difficult time hiring management staff for factory locations, they also have a difficult time vetting the people they do hire or promote from within. I have never encountered so many people who work at a level well below what their title requires.

job_title: Associate Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Employee discounts are very generous.
Met some great colleagues.

Learned a lot in my role and lots of classes available for self growth.
cons:
Little room for career growth, moving up in title and salary. No matter how hard you work or prioritize your job. Which goes hand in hand with work life balance. There was none. 

The “Way forward” was all talk and sounded ideal but no progress really was made. Too many of upper management are old timers with their set ways. 

Working from home was stressful as VP was not used to this way of working. Constantly checked in via IM to make sure we were at our computers all day.

pros:
Relatively simple work (fold clothes, assist customers with finding sizes, ring at cashier, sell items)

Employee discount is very generous and you will find yourself buying very nice Ralph Lauren items for next to nothing. You WILL end up very well dressed

Generally fun people to work with 

Meeting customers from other countries is always interesting

Management implemented rewards programs for exceptional employees (like giving away gift cards, etc)
cons:
No commission despite working in a high volume sales environment

Usually required to work closing shifts (meaning cleaning a really messy store until midnight and sometimes later)

Working weekends is required

Very busy, can get hectic and stressful

Pay is your basic shopping mall hourly wage--not much at all

You will occasionally come across a rude or entitled customer

job_title: Accounts Payable in High Point, NC
pros: Benefits were superior to other local employers. The floating holidays as well as the basic holidays are better than any other employers in the South. The company is very stable. The economic downturn was hardly felt while I was with the company. The philanthropic activities also give you a great pride working here. Ralph Lauren himself is such an iconic man.
cons: The people at the company tend to be very cookie cutter especially in the customer service department. It looks like it could be a fashion show. The company is quick to restructure all kinds of areas and cut jobs. Their treatment of the employees who are cut isn't great. There isn't much room to move up either.

review_title: Great Company! Lot's of Growth Opportunity!
job_title: Brand Manager in New York, NY
pros: Thoroughly enjoyed my time at RL. I had been there for several years and met a lot of wonderful people throughout that time. Lot's of growth opportunity in my department. Co-workers were all great. We all love what we do, so it was always fun.
cons: There were really no cons. Sometimes we worked long hours, but that is to be expected in any corporate role.

review_title: a bright future for the next 50 years
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

review_title: It's a difficult company to work for long term.

pros: Great company to have on your résumé. Great discounts on merchandise and the designers you work with are very knowledgable and friendly.
cons: The environment is very negative and employees are generally overworked under paid and under appreciated. There is little advancement and no perks (bonuses or raises). It's a revolving door.

review_title: Worthwhile if you're in it for the long haul

review_title: Must have strong backbone, love of style, be prompt to work, and love working with the public.

review_title: Great people, decent pay. Excellent company to gain wide-range of experience.  High energy. Recommend for hard workers.

Never boring.
Amazing Talent in company.

High pay bonus opportunity.

Mngrs avg 48hr wks in high volume locations, not compensated.

Talent 'can be' under appreciated.

review_title: It is a great company with great opportunity for growth. Also its a company that carries quality products.

review_title: I’m scared of working retail again

review_title: The Company supports their employees career aspirations

cons: With a large company like Ralph Lauren, some processes are in place that slow down change. It often feels like there are too many directions the company is moving in.

review_title: Somewhere in the middle of a good and bad company.

Wages are stagnant, and do not reflect volume of a store.
There is no real room for advancement if you desire it.

Sales goals are often unrealistic, and unattainable.

People that work there are cool

review_title: Strong company, Very political, Great benefits

job_title: Assistant to Ralph Lauren in New York, NY
pros: Marvelous Boss! Working for Ralph was one of the highlights of my unique career. I learned so much from him. I gained a lot of knowledge in how you successfully run a company and how you treat your employees. Well-Diversified, Fantastic perks, Unique individuals, Beautiful space!
cons:
No mentor, few job opportunities, no open door policy.
The salary wasn't realistic for New York. Being the Assistant to Ralph Lauren, it was difficult to stay with-in the company and gain respect for my "own" accomplishments. I found that people were not so receptive but Ralph was amazing and stayed in contact, even after I left the New York office.

job_title: P&D Director in New York, NY

Pride in the brand is strong in all parts of the business!
Learning & Development support for employees is great in the company in you have the time to take the classes!
Currently there is a lot of change which lends itself to cross functional projects and learning. 
Increased effort on communication means that the company strategy and purpose is cascading and clear to understand. Fosters transparency and high trust environment. 
Recognition tools are available which offer an easy way to pay it back.
The discount is great!
cons: Not all office spaces lend themselves to collaborative work environment. In certain parts of the business there can be a hierarchical structure that delays decision making.

pros: PTO, benefits, discount, challenging work

Years of restructuring has changed the mindset to that of survival, which fosters finger pointing, diminishing others wins, tons of red tape, and lack of collaboration.  Many are unmotivated and feel undervalued.

review_title: Excellent, high energy environment that focuses on growth and development with their employees!
pros: Ralph Lauren strives to create a world class customer service environment through intense talent and development training of the staff.  They invest time into getting the "Right people in the right places" and provide multiple opportunities for advancement within the company.  They have a very well tenured staff (part time through corporate) who genuinely enjoy their job and the people they work for/with.
cons: No set schedule (retail environment).  Due to the amount of traffic in the building it is a strenuous job that requires a high level of energy and motivation.

pros: Endless opportunity for personal and professional growth. Constant challenge. Positive energetic work atmosphere. Clearly defined goals for promotions. The business is structured for individuals to grow. The focus is on building and growing individuals to become the better versions of themselves.
cons: The con of this business is that it will challenge you, you will be exposed. Failure is a part of success and success is a measure of the individual and their correct actions/behavior. The con is that politics plays no part here. This is a merit based business that attracts high performers willing to accept responsibility for their growth/success or lack thereof. Simple but not easy. Hard work is a must!

Keyholder status was abused by management.  Required to do managements duties as they were typically out of the store.  The bonus for being a keyholder was not enough to offset the extra work added to your duties and took you off the floor which made it difficult to meet sales goals.  

Unrealistic sales goals for Sales Professionals and for the Departments/Store as well.

pros: Powerful brand. Young teams with good people within them. Good working space, in house cantine. Potential for growth and improvement

Needs to focus more on top quality to be considered a luxury brand.

review_title: Strong brand, not much else going for it.
job_title: Supply Chain Analyst in Greensboro, NC
pros:
Middle management is competent and compassionate.
Working conditions are very comfortable, benefits are generous.
The company survives on it's well-established branding; it will be strong on that alone for many years.

Office applications are woefully out-of-date.  Compensation for non-management employees is below average; bonuses and raises are meager considering the company's stock-price is higher than it's ever been.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

job_title: Cash Wrap Lead in San Marcos, TX

pros: Product, discount and benefits. Associates
